name: Straw Man
definition: Misrepresenting someone's position to make it easier to attack.
whyItWorks: It's easier to defeat a caricature than a nuanced position. By exaggerating or distorting, we can 'win' against a version of the argument that was never actually made.

examples.text: Immigration hawks want to deport every immigrant and seal the border permanently.
examples.analysis: Most supporters of stricter enforcement distinguish between legal and illegal immigration and don't advocate for zero immigration.

examples.text: Cancel culture critics think people should be able to say anything with zero consequences.
examples.analysis: Most critics distinguish between proportional social consequences and disproportionate mob punishment. They're not advocating for zero accountability.

examples.text: Prison reformers want to let dangerous criminals walk free with no punishment.
examples.analysis: Most reformers focus on non-violent offenders and advocate for rehabilitation alongside consequences, not eliminating accountability.

examples.text: Health skeptics think all natural supplements are snake oil and only trust Big Pharma.
examples.analysis: Most skeptics simply want evidence-based claims; they're not reflexively pro-pharmaceutical or anti-natural.

examples.text: People concerned about political violence just want to silence all criticism of public figures.
examples.analysis: Concern about violence isn't the same as opposing criticism. Most people distinguish between harsh speech and incitement.

promptStarters: The other side wants us to believe that ___, which is ridiculous.
They basically think we should just ___.
So you're saying we should ___ and let ___ happen?
Their position is essentially that ___, which no sane person would support.
